Feature Article Manipulating polymerization chemistry of Cr/silica catalysts through calcination Max McDaniel Phillips Research Center, Bartlesville, OK, 74004, United States Phillips Research Center Bartlesville OK 74004 United States Graphical abstract The calcination temperature of Cr/silica catalyst is varied over a wide range to manipulate HDPE characteristics for many diverse applications, such as the three seen here: large pipe, cable coating, and milk containers. More than any other parameter, the calcination process is capable of modifying the performance of the Cr/silica catalyst system (also known as Phillips-type catalysts) to generate activity and to influence the diverse active population in order to produce a wide variety of different polymer characteristics. This includes the polymer molecular weight, the shape and breadth of the MW distribution, the efficiency of comonomer and macromer incorporation, and the location of both short-chain and long-chain branches within the MW distribution. These fundamental polymer characteristics control how the polymer behaves during molding operations and they influence every physical property of the finished HDPE part. For this reason, a considerable number of calcination recipes have been developed over 60 years of commercial use to tailor the polymer characteristics for various HDPE applications. This is done by manipulating the relative amounts of differing active sites on the catalyst. This report attempts to explain the chemistry involved in the calcination process, to show how it can be controlled in various ways to achieve commercial ends, and to extrapolate these trends to predict the future of catalyst activation in the HDPE industry. Keywords Catalyst calcination Phillips catalyst Catalyst activation Polyethylene Chromium catalyst Ethylene polymerization Polymerization catalyst Commercial activation HDPE 1 Introduction The Cr/silica ethylene polymerization catalyst system, usually known in the PE industry as the Phillips catalyst due to its discovery in 1951 at Phillips Petroleum Company, is used to manufacture a large share of the world’s most widely used plastic, high density polyethylene (HDPE) [1]. In order to be active the catalyst must first be calcined (also called the activation), which if done correctly can bind each chromium atom individually to the silica support in the hexavalent form [2–11] The selection of temperature and calcination protocol not only determines the activity of the catalyst, but also how efficiently it runs in the commercial reactors, and even the type of polymers made, which includes such fundamental characteristics as the polymer molecular weight (MW), the breath of the MW distribution, the degree to which comonomer and macromer are incorporated, and the subsequent distribution of short- and long-chain branches within the MW distribution. All of these characteristics are extremely important in determining how the polymer will perform in various applications, including the molding behavior and the final physical properties of the finished HDPE part. Consequently, many variations and adaptations of the Phillips catalyst system have been invented over 60 years of commercial use. In fact, no other polymerization catalyst is capable of delivering such a wide variety of commercial polymer types or serves such a diverse field of applications. The catalyst contains a diverse assortment of active site types, each of which produces its own characteristic type of polymer, and the combination produces the observed polymer character. Polymer performance is manipulated by adjusting the relative amounts of these active site types through catalyst chemistry. A large fraction of these catalyst variations involve modification of the calcination temperature or procedure. For example, polymers can be made to vary in MW from simple wax to ultra-high MW, used in bullet-proof armor. Or, long-chain branching can be varied from zero (“lossy” polymers) in film grades to high (elastic polymers) in geomembrane grades. Or the MW breadth can be narrow for injection molding grades, like that from Ziegler catalysts, or extremely broad, having polydispersity indices over 100, which is useful in pipe [12]. In this paper we review some of the chemistry involved in the catalyst activation process and discuss how it has been applied to improve the resultant polymer. Most of the scientific literature on the Phillips catalyst concentrates on spectroscopic examination, in all its many forms, which can indeed be a useful way of studying any catalyst. However, only a small fraction of the chromium is thought to be active on the Phillips commercial catalysts, and consequently one is never certain whether it is the active or dead form of chromium that is being observed spectroscopically. In contrast, the one sure way of exclusively probing only the active sites is by studying the amount and type polymer they produce. Although this approach has rarely been used in the literature, it has by necessity been done by an army of industrial chemists for over 65 years. In this paper we attempt to summarize this wealth of information and the mechanistic inferences that can be derived from them. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Simple laboratory calcination In the most simple (laboratory) form of activation, Cr/silica catalyst having a low loading of chromium (<0.5Cr/nm2) is placed in a shallow (a few cm) fluidized bed using dry air or oxygen as the fluidization gas. The temperature is ramped up linearly, usually over a period of one to three hours, to the hold temperature, which is typically between 400°C and 900°C. The catalyst is held at that temperature for usually 3–12h, after which it is cooled in the same atmosphere. The final step is to flush out the oxygen with nitrogen or another inert gas at temperatures less than 250°C. When done correctly this procedure can quantitatively convert the chromium into Cr(VI) which reacts with silanols groups to attach to the surface as chromate or dichromate esters. The process is illustrated in Scheme 1 , starting with hexavalent CrO3. However, trivalent chromium compounds are also frequently used, being oxidized to Cr(VI) during the calcination. The chromium loading is particularly important because, although bulk CrO3 decomposes into α-Cr2O3 when heated above about 200°C [13], esterification with the silica surface can stabilize the Cr(VI) against higher temperatures [14,15]. However, if the useable silanol population is fully reacted with chromium, the surface becomes saturated and the excess Cr is converted into α-Cr2O3. Because the available silanol population is a function of temperature, as depicted in Scheme 1, so also is the amount of Cr(VI) that can be stabilized on the surface [16]. For example, a 4wt% Cr catalyst could be fully hexavalent at 300°C but lose most of its Cr(VI) to α-Cr2O3 at 900°C. The calcination temperature determines not only the amount of Cr(VI) that can be stabilized, but also the “character” of that surface Cr(VI). Scheme 1 attempts to illustrate this. Notice in the upper part that silanols on plain silica condense to siloxanes as the temperature is raised, also releasing water which is carried away in the gas stream. At low calcination temperatures closely neighboring OH groups exist, some of which condense as the temperature is raised, leaving the remaining silanols more isolated. Thus OH condensation becomes increasingly difficult with rising temperature. This has been well established by the study of silanol reactivity with “sequestering” reagents such as BCl3, BH3. Si(CH3)2Cl2, AlCl3, TiCl4, and CrO2Cl2 [17–24]. It also implies that these isolated silanols are either not highly mobile on the annealed surface, or are otherwise not able to condense. In the lower portion of Scheme 1 the same transformation is illustrated for a Cr/silica catalyst. At low temperatures esterification of CrO3 is relative easy due to the multitude of closely spaced surface hydroxyls. However, at higher temperature the silanols become more separated and esterification with CrO3 becomes more difficult. The spacing of Cr(VI) bonding with silanols probably also changes with calcination temperature. Si-O-Cr-O-Si linkages become more strained as the silanols become more separated, as depicted in Scheme 1 [25–28]. Strain would tend to pull the Cr away from the shared oxide orbitals (much like a tight bridge influences metallocenes). Potential ligands from neighboring OH groups are also removed at higher temperatures. Both of these effects would tend to enhance electron deficiency, or Lewis acidity, increasing the positive charge on the chromium. The net result of these changes is summarized in Table 1 . In this experiment a simple Cr/silica catalyst containing 0.38Cr(VI)/nm2 was calcined in dry oxygen at temperatures ranging from 400°C to 900°C and then each was tested in ethylene polymerization. Notice in Table 1 that the available silanol population (measured on plain silica similarly calcined) decreased with temperature. Also shown in Table 1 is the maximum amount of Cr(VI) that could be stabilized, which also decreased with rising temperature [16,29]. It is interesting that the values in these two rows are similar. When the loading is maximized dichromate begins to dominate over chromate because dichromate can tolerate wider silanol spacing, and only uses one silanol per chromium, whereas chromate uses two links to the surface [19]. Thus, Table 1 also shows that, for a constant Cr loading of 0.38Cr/nm2, the proportion of Cr(VI) present as dichromate was found to rise with temperature. This may explain why the color of the catalyst changes from yellow (chromate) to orange (dichromate) with rising calcination temperature, as shown in Fig. 1 . The red catalyst will be discussed below under the heading “High Melt Index Activations”. The activity of the catalysts in Table 1, which was measured at a constant loading of 0.38Cr(VI)/nm2, increased strongly with rising calcination temperature. This is undoubtedly a consequence of enhanced Lewis acidity. One could argue that it both raises the proportion of active Cr, versus dead Cr, and that barely active sites become invigorated with greater electron deficiency. The stronger Lewis acidity should be more reactive with the pi-electrons of ethylene. Notice also in Table 1 that the melt index and the high load melt index of the polymer [30] are greatly increased with rising calcination temperature [31,32]. These are two fluidity (inverse viscosity) measurements commonly used throughout the PE industry to indicate the ease of flow of the molten polymer. Higher melt index values usually indicate lower molecular weight, which is confirmed in Table 1, showing the weight-average MW. Enhanced Lewis acidity encourages agostic coordination with the β-hydride on the polymer chain to the Cr, which is a necessary first step toward chain termination, that is, toward lower MW. Steric changes to the Cr coordination sphere may also accompany rising temperature, as ligands are removed. A more open environment also encourages agostic β-hydride coordination. Table 1 shows that the breadth of the MW distribution narrows significantly, i.e. the polydispersity drops, as the calcination temperature is raised, which brings new active sites on stream. Fig. 2 shows MW distributions from each of the catalysts in Table 1. The GPC curves in the upper half of Fig. 2 are normalized by the activity of the catalyst, so that one can see where the new polymer contributions are made due to the higher activity as the calcination temperature is raised. Notice that the new (or newly modified) active sites produce polymer mainly in the mid-to-low MW range, which accounts for the narrowing distribution. In the lower half of Fig. 2 the very same GPC curves are again plotted, but this time as a polymer specialist would view them, i.e. all normalized to equal area. From this perspective one can see a significant “loss” from the high-MW and low-MW tails. These changes are extreme in terms of polymer behavior, and they illustrate why so many different types of polymers have been made with the Phillips catalyst, to serve so many diverse molding applications. Another important change in the catalyst that occurs with rising activation temperature is enhanced reactivity with α-olefin. Phillips catalysts are typically 30–50 times more reactive with ethylene than with larger comonomers, typically 1-hexene. However, at high calcination temperature they become more efficient, so that at a fixed 1-hexene concentration in the reactor more branching is obtained in the polymer. An example is shown in Table 2 . The upper half of the table shows the branching obtained from a Cr/silica catalyst activated at 600°C and also at 900°C. Each of these two catalysts was tested at the same ethylene and 1-hexene concentration in the reactor. Notice that the catalyst activated at 600°C incorporated 8.8 branches per 1000 carbons, whereas the 900°C catalyst incorporated 12.4 branches per 1000 carbons, about 40% more. Like the MW response described above, this response to 1-hexene is also thought to be a consequence of the stronger Lewis acidity. Since α-olefin is a better electron donor than ethylene, its incorporation is enhanced on the more electron-deficient catalyst. The same trend is observed from tightly bridged metallocenes (also more electron deficient) versus their more loosely bridged counterparts [33]. Of course the steric component, which is more difficult to determine on Cr/silica catalysts, is also cited as another contributing factor, since tight bridging better exposes the Zr. The amount of 1-hexene incorporation by the 600°C Cr/silica catalyst is plotted in Fig. 3 as a function of the molecular weight [34]. One can see that it is the low-MW producing sites that tend to be better at incorporating comonomer, both tendencies (low-MW and comonomer incorporation) being dependent on Lewis acidity. Thus, branching tends to be concentrated into the low-MW part of the MW distribution. The GPC curve in Fig. 3 has been deconvoluted into seven Schultz-Flory (SF) components, representing seven theoretical site types. (This is not to say that there are only seven site types. Rather, seven is the minimum number of components needed to faithfully reproduce the GPC curve.) Branching coefficients were then assigned to each component, shown in Table 2, so that the branch profile in Fig. 3 could also be faithfully reproduced. Fig. 3 plots both the measured branch concentration and also the branch profile calculated from these coefficients. Then the exercise was repeated but using the polymer from the 900°C Cr/silica catalyst, which is also shown in Fig. 3 and Table 2. As expected, it was easy to reproduce the new GPC curve from the same seven Schultz-Flory components shown earlier for the 600°C catalyst. This was accomplished just by changing the relative amounts of each component. Surprisingly, however, it was then found that this combination also reproduced the new 900°C branch profile, without any readjustment of the branching coefficients. Notice in Table 2 that the same branching coefficients were used to reproduce the observed branch profile from both catalysts. This is an indication that the overall site character was not affected by the increase in activation temperature, only a redistribution of these same site-types. In summary, a simple repopulation of these same seven components can independently reproduce both the MW distribution and also the branch profiles from both catalysts. The experiment was repeated using a Cr/silica-titania catalyst calcined at 500°C and at 900°C. Again the high temperature catalyst incorporated more 1-hexene, by about two fold. The deconvolution results are shown in the lower half of Table 2. This time, although the two GPC curves could be reproduced by a repopulation of the same seven components, the branching profile could not be reproduced. New, and very different, branching coefficients had to be re-assigned to the 900°C components to match experimental results. This suggests that the increased calcination temperature produced very different sites. Other observations also indicate this, such as the overall shape of the branch profile. It was nearly flat at 500°C but concentrated in the low-MW end at 900°C. This and the shape of the GPC curve, suggest that high temperature tends to move Cr off of the titania, or at least to modify its bonding in some way. The Phillips catalyst typically produces chains with a methyl group on one end and a terminal vinyl group on the other. This vinyl group can then insert much like comonomer, hence the term “macromonomer” or just “macromer”. Thus, macromer is another type of α-olefin that can be incorporated as a branch into a growing polymer chain [35–37]. The result is a “long-chain branch” (LCB) as shown in Scheme 2 . Long-chain branching occurs very infrequently (it is measured in branches per million carbons) but it nevertheless has a profound effect on polymer molding behavior because it becomes entangled with other chains, and thus serves as an “anchor point” which resists flow at low shear. Consequently, LCB influences swell and melt fracture in blow molding, clarity and bubble stability in film, resistance to flow, stress crack resistance and melt strength in all applications, and many other performance characteristics. Therefore, control of LCB is a matter of great importance in HDPE manufacturing, and this is done by manipulating catalyst variables, especially the calcination step. One can see in Table 1 that long-chain branching increased with rising calcination temperature. Like other α-olefins, macromer is a better electron donor than ethylene, and the stronger Lewis acidity at high calcination temperature tends to enhance its incorporation. In summary, because the calcination temperature controls the breadth of the MW distribution (and thus the MW for a given flow resistance), and the amount and pattern of both short-chain and long-chain branching, it is not surprising that it also has a major influence on every polymer performance characteristic known. Two examples are shown in Table 1. In the first example the environmental stress crack resistance (ESCR) is listed as a function of calcination temperature. ESCR is a measure of how resistant a stressed polymer sample is toward attack by chemicals like detergents at elevated temperature. Polymers were made using Cr/silica catalysts calcined at various temperatures, and the ESCR rating obtained from each polymer is shown in the table. In each experiment the density (short-chain branching) and melt index of the polymer were adjusted to a constant value using the 1-hexene feed and reaction temperature. The ESCR value listed in the table is the number of hours the sample lasted before breakage. It is clear that ESCR is favored by low calcination temperature, due to the broader MW distribution, the lower degree of LCB, and relatively more branching in the high MW region. In the second example in Table 1 a film resin was made using catalysts calcined at various temperatures. Again the density and melt index were held constant (which defines the commercial grade specification) by adjusting 1-hexene feed and reactor temperature. Film of about 25μm thickness was then blown from each polymer sample under HDPE line conditions. These films were then subjected to a standard puncture test in which a weighted dart was dropped onto them from 66cm, increasing the weight until the film finally broke. This value is shown in Table 1. Again, low calcination temperature was greatly preferred, although perhaps for slightly different reasons. The broader MW distribution was favored because it produces a higher MW for a given melt index grade specification. The low LCB value produced low relaxation time, which minimized the tendency for orientation in a single direction. Put simply, PE molecules become elongated and oriented during extrusion and blowing, and then they try to relax back before cooling and solidifying to lose their orientation. Low LCB provides faster relaxation due to fewer “anchor” points (entanglements) in the molten PE. Thus, in both of these examples, the catalyst chemist must compromise between plant operations (which prefer high temperature) and polymer properties (which favor low temperature). 2.2 Cr(VI) mobility Another important reaction that occurs during calcination is chromium (VI) mobility [38]. Surprisingly, hexavalent Cr is very mobile during calcination, moving not only within the 100μm (average) silica particle but even between particles. Cr(VI) does not travel via gas-phase but rather through direct particle-to-particle contact during fluidization. Scheme 3 illustrates how Cr(VI) might move by hydrolysis or redox cycling. In the absence of oxygen less transfer is observed. Fig. 4 shows two examples of Cr(VI) mobility. In the upper half, two experiments are shown in which a quartz tube was packed with silica on the bottom and then with Cr(III)/silica on top. Both components had been previously dried at 200°C to remove any adsorbed moisture. Dry gas was then passed downward through the packed bed, which is opposite to the usual fluidized bed activation where the gas flows upward. In the left experiment the gas was nitrogen and in the right it was air. The temperature was then raised to 800°C where it was held for three hours. Afterward it was cooled to 25°C. After calcination both beds were still found to contain the two bands of catalyst and silica, with a demarcation in between. But notice that the fixed catalyst bed calcined in nitrogen (left) is green from Cr2O3 and has a very sharp color line demarcating the two components. In contrast the catalyst bed calcined in air (right) is orange indicating conversion to Cr(VI) and has a softer, less distinct demarcation. This blurred band is due to migration of the chromium, even within a fixed bed. There is much more contact between particles in a fluidized bed and consequently Cr(VI) migration is also much easier. One example of this is shown in the lower half of Fig. 4 [38]. Silica was impregnated with aqueous CrO3 to a loading of 5wt% Cr, which is too high to be stabilized at high temperature. Therefore when it was activated in dry air at 900°C, 80% of the chromium decomposed to α-Cr2O3. This is the green material in the lower part of Fig. 4, called “hardened α-Cr2O3” because it is considered impossible to reoxidize. However, this material was then dry-mixed with four parts of virgin silica (dried only at 200°C to remove adsorbed moisture) and the mixture was calcined in dry air at 900°C in a fluidized bed. It turned orange, indicating full re-conversion to Cr(VI). This could only have happened if the chromium was able to migrate from the green 5% Cr sample to the virgin surface of the added silica. Even bulk α-chromia could be dry-mixed with silica and calcined in a fluidized bed to form an acceptable Cr(VI)/silica catalyst. Cr(VI) mobility is important in commercial operations because catalysts are frequently made by spray drying, which tends to concentrate the chromium into the smaller particles, and through chromatography onto the exterior of particles. There is so much movement during calcination that the chromium redistributes evenly through and between particles. Mobility is also necessary in some of the specialty activations described below. 2.3 Reduction Sometimes Cr(VI) catalysts are also reduced during the calcination process by a final exposure to carbon monoxide, hydrogen, methane, olefin vapor or other hydrocarbon. Such treatments are sometimes used commercially to shorten the induction time [1,39–41] or to produce branching in-situ during ethylene polymerization [42–49]. Even when the catalyst is not reduced during calcination, it is still reduced by ethylene from Cr(VI) to a lower valent species when it is introduced into the reactor. The oxidation state of the active catalyst has long been controversial, starting from the discovery of the catalyst right up until the present. Exposure of the catalyst to various reducing treatments often generates a very prominent Cr(V) ESR signal [50–56]. Early researchers tried to correlate this signal with the catalyst activity, often concluding that the “active valence” (active precursor) was Cr(V) or in one case Cr(IV) [57–59] based on a perceived inverse correlation. Others thought Cr2O3, or isolated Cr(III) ions, were the active precursor, which were sometimes claimed to be more active than the commercial catalysts [60–64]. This claim was based on vacuum line studies and could not be confirmed in this laboratory under higher pressure and temperature. Vacuum line polymerization has been a common pitfall and should inspire caution about making such sweeping extrapolations. Usually these early studies did not distinguish between an “active species” and an “active precursor”. Conclusions about valence were usually based on measurements made before contact with ethylene, and therefore a more accurate term would have been “active site precursor”. More recently Coperet et al. [65] proposed Cr(III) as the active precursor, and also as the active polymerization site after contact with ethylene. This conclusion was based on organic model compounds of Cr(II) and Cr(III). When deposited onto silica and pyrolized at 400°C, the Cr(II) model compound was found to be inactive, even though the commercial Cr(II) species being modeled does initiate polymerization vigorously. In contrast, a Cr(III) model compound was found to be active. Therefore it is useful to review some relevant information. Calcination of the Cr(VI) catalyst in carbon monoxide, when done correctly, converts the Cr(VI) almost quantitatively to Cr(II) as shown in Scheme 4 . This was established quite early through actual titration [66–73]. CO reduces the hexavalent catalyst even at room temperature, but at least 300°C is preferred in order to drive the reaction to completion in a short time, and to prevent adsorption of CO when the catalyst is afterward flushed out with nitrogen. When exposed to air, Cr(II)/silica is oxidized back to the hexavalent form with a brilliant flash of chemiluminescence [15,66,68,70,74], as shown in Fig. 5 . This Cr(II) version of the Phillips catalyst initiates polymerization rapidly and it is sometimes used interchangeably with Cr(VI) in commercial practice. The two catalysts display only subtle differences. Cr(II) exhibits a shortened induction time, which is reasonable given that it is already reduced. The molecular weight distributions produced are very similar when comparing Cr(VI)/silica versus Cr(II)/silica or Cr(II)/alumina versus Cr(VI)/alumina. An example is shown in Fig. 6 . The main differences between Cr(II)/silica compared to Cr(VI)/silica are: 1) a slight shift to higher MW, which can be seen in Figs. 6, and 2) better comonomer incorporation efficiency. We suspect that when Cr(VI) is reduced by ethylene, the oxidized organic product is still coordinated to the chromium, unlike the clean Cr(II)/silica catalyst. This fact may account for some of the differences, such as the enhanced copolymerization efficiency. We have also observed that in titrations of catalyst activity with traces of strong poisons, Cr(II) tolerates a little more poison than Cr(VI) before dying. Usually this difference is about 1 poison per Cr, which is again consistent with Cr(VI) retaining a redox ligand. It is particularly interesting to compare the two forms of Cr/silica-titania catalysts. The presence of titania renders the Cr(VI) more reactive with ethylene, as indicated by TPR studies [75,76] and partial reduction in CO [1,77] . The addition of titania introduces a large new population of low-MW producing sites, so that the MW distribution is broadened on the low-MW side. However, if (after a normal calcination in air) the catalyst is partially reduced in CO at low temperatures (25°C–200°C) and cooled in CO, the reduced sites are rendered inactive due to adsorption of CO, whereas the unreduced Cr(VI) site remain active when contacted with ethylene. The activity, of course drops as more sites are reduced and poisoned. Such partial reduction seems to kill those same Ti-associated sites first. An example is shown in Fig. 7 . The MW distribution narrows as sites and activity are lost. This trend is exactly opposite to what is observed as titania is added to the catalyst [1]. It suggests that the Ti-associated sites are most easily reduced (most acidic). Fig. 8 shows the MW distribution and branch profile from Cr(VI)/silica-titania. One of the great advantages of titania addition is the loss of branching on the low-MW side of the MW distribution. The new Ti-associated sites do not incorporate branches very efficiently, or perhaps they tend to terminate chains right after comonomer insertion, so that no branch results. Consequently the branch profile is flattened on the low-MW side where the Ti contributes, which enhances most polymer physical properties. Also shown in Fig. 8 is the MW distribution and branch profile from Cr(II)/silica-titania. After being calcined in air, they were then treated with CO at 350°C, and cooled in N2. Notice that the Ti-associated sites again seem to be affected most by CO-reduction. They no longer produce the same low-MW polymer as before, and so the MW distribution has been truncated on the low-MW side. However, unlike the catalysts in Fig. 7 which were partially poisoned by CO, these CO-reduced catalysts were more active than Cr(VI) because they were not poisoned. The Ti-associated sites now also incorporate branching efficiently so that the branch profile has changed to that expected from Cr/silica (Fig. 3), with more branching in the low-MW region. This may mean that the Ti-associated sites have migrated from the Ti, or it may be connected with the loss of a redox ligand, although the details are not yet fully understood. That Cr(II)/silica catalysts initiate polymerization so well is not to say that Cr(II) is the active valence during polymerization. Cr(II) is probably oxidized by ethylene in the process of becoming alkylated. The simplest conceivable initiation reaction, through a macrocycle as shown in Scheme 5 , would produce a dialkylated Cr(IV) species. It is interesting that tetravalent chromium alkyls, which form such species when deposited onto a support [78–81], are indeed active at 80–100°C in the commercial process and they produce polymer similar to that from chromium oxides. The same can be said of chromium (II) alkyls, which are also active when deposited onto a support, as shown in Scheme 5, and which could produce a similar species. In another recent work, Scott et al. [82,83] attempted to address this point, and concluded that Cr(II) is oxidized by ethylene not to Cr(IV), as in Scheme 5, but to Cr(III) which was proposed as the active valence during polymerization. This conclusion was based on spectroscopic and computational studies, which can be difficult when only a small fraction of the chromium is active [1,4,14,77,84]. In order to accommodate a one-electron oxidation of the Cr(II) by a two-electron oxidant (ethylene), free radical fragments were proposed as a side product. In fact many organochromium compounds which can form similar divalent species are known to be active when deposited onto a support, and produce polymer similar to the corresponding Cr oxide catalysts [85–88]. This includes diallyl chromium [88,89], bis-2,4-dimethylpentadienyl chromium [87], and even the diarene chromium(0) compounds [88,90,91], which release H2 upon binding, probably indicating oxidization to divalent species. Chromocene, which loses one cyclopentadienyl ligand upon attachment to the support [92,93], is also quite active, but the polymer it produces is different, suggesting that it retains one Cp ligand up to about 90–100°C, beyond which its behavior becomes more like the other organo-Cr compounds [92]. Thus, any proposal for the active site must also take these other Cr catalyst variations into account. There are two major operational differences between these organochromium catalysts and their chromium oxide counterparts: 1) they become very sensitive to hydrogen as a polymer MW-regulator, and 2) they produce small amounts of light olefins, 1-hexene in particular, which incorporate into the polymer as branching, although at low levels. By observing which supports produce more of these olefins, we believe that both of these traits come from a monodentate-bonded organo-Cr species (Scheme 6 ), which is present in at least some small amount on nearly all supports treated with organochromium compounds. Again the exception is chromocene, which does not produce these olefins until the cyclopentadienyl ligand comes off at about 90°C [92]. Any proposal for the “active valence” on the Phillips catalyst must take all of these observations into account, and surely the accumulation of all of this data out-weighs any single experiment. It is conceivable that two or more valences are capable of polymerization, which if true would be another caution against extrapolating any single laboratory study to the commercial world. However, the character of the polymer, which in our opinion is the best window we have into the nature of the active sites, argues for a common explanation. 2.4 Commercial activation In HDPE manufacturing plants Cr/silica is calcined in much the same way it is done in the laboratory. That is, a batch process is used in which the catalyst bed is fluidized and the temperature is ramped up (usually approximately linearly) in dry air to the desired maximum temperature, where it is held for typically 8–30h. The equipment is similar to the lab, but the bed is much deeper, up to 8 feet compared to a few inches in the lab. Due to the larger equipment, the commercial ramp rate is necessarily slower, the hold time is longer, and the air flow rate is higher, made possible by filters that return entrained catalyst (blow-over) to the fluidized bed. These differences have some major consequences for the catalyst. During calcination Cr(VI) is stabilized by attachment to the silica surface. However, the presence of small amounts of moisture can hydrolyze these attachments, and then the Cr(VI) can thermally decompose to Cr2O3 [94,95]. This is why the fluidization air feed stream is kept extremely dry. If the α-Cr2O3 crystallites have not grown too large, however, the Cr(III) can be reoxidized to Cr(VI) so that an equilibrium is set up between Cr(VI) and Cr(III). Consequently a steady-state Cr(VI) content is reached which is a function of the moisture vapor level, the temperature, and the oxygen level. This is illustrated in the lower part of Scheme 3. Table 3 shows a laboratory example of this sensitivity. A commercial catalyst, having 300m2/g surface area and loaded to 0.9wt% chromium, was calcined in a fluidized bed at various temperatures in air to which known levels of moisture were deliberately added. After three hours the calcination was stopped and the amount of Cr(VI) retained on each catalyst was measured by redox titration. Notice that at 400°C and 500°C there was little or no loss in Cr(VI) as the moisture level was increased. However, at 600°C and above the moisture began to lower Cr(VI), and the higher the temperature the greater the sensitivity. At 800°C and 3% moisture in the gas stream most of the Cr(VI) was lost. This equilibrium is also a function of the oxygen content in the gas. Higher Cr(VI) conversion is usually observed with pure oxygen compared to air. If oxygen is completely removed from the gas stream, a slow decline in Cr(VI) is observed. An example of this sensitivity is shown below in Table 4 . Samples of the same Cr/silica catalyst (as in Table 3) were calcined in dry air at 650°C or 800°C to convert the chromium to Cr(VI). Then each was heated for various times in nitrogen at 350°C, 650°C or 800°C. Even at 350°C there was some loss of Cr(VI) over two days, but at 800°C the loss was extreme and rapid. This shows the role of oxygen in the redox equilibrium of Scheme 3. In commercial operations any trace of moisture in the calcination air stream is first removed by dryer beds. However, the catalyst surface itself emits significant moisture as silanol groups condense to siloxanes during heat-up. Therefore the deeper beds used in commercial calcinations produce much higher moisture concentrations than are produced during a lab activation. Consequently Cr(VI) values from commercial activations are rarely as high as that from similar lab calcinations. There is also a frequent desire during manufacturing to increase output from the calcination equipment, which means larger catalyst charges and thus deeper beds. This works against the quality of the catalyst, and inevitably compromises must be made. Fig. 9 shows the effect of bed depth on conversion to Cr(VI). In this laboratory experiment a glass tube was filled with Cr/silica catalyst to a depth of about one foot. Then the air flow was reversed so that the gas flowed downward, producing a fixed static bed, not the usual fluidized bed. After calcination at 800°C one could see a color gradient through the bed with primarily orange, or Cr(VI), at the top and primarily green, or Cr(III), on the bottom. The catalyst at the bottom had been exposed to all of the moisture released by the catalyst above it. In a fluidized bed the same forces are at work, but because the particles move around rapidly in the bed the loss in Cr(VI) is averaged over all of the catalyst particles. The loss of Cr(VI) can be mitigated by: 1) increasing the oxygen content in the gas steam, which is not practical on a commercial scale, or 2) by minimizing the catalyst’s exposure to moisture. For this reason, commercial activations typically use five times the linear flow rate of air than are practical in the laboratory. Filters on top of commercial activators keep the catalyst from being entrained and blown out at this rate. Nevertheless, when the air flow is expressed in the more relevant terms of space velocity (how rapidly the bed air is exchanged with new air) the lab activator still has an advantage over the commercial equipment, offering higher space velocity, so that it tends to produce higher conversion to Cr(VI). When the commercial and lab Cr(VI) values are plotted against space velocity, however, they do fall on the same line. An example of this is shown in Fig. 10 . Notice in Fig. 10 that there are two curves and that they correspond to two different ramp-up rates to the hold temperature. Since the silanol condensation rate, and therefore the moisture emission rate, is a function of temperature change, the faster ramp rate produces higher concentrations of moisture. That is, the same amount of water is released overall, but at a faster rate which increases the concentration of moisture. Therefore a slow ramp-rate is preferred for best catalyst quality, but not for maximum production. So again, compromises must inevitably be made. TGA curves can be obtained to allow calculation of moisture emission at any temperature, and, with a calibration curve such as Fig. 10 or Table 3, one can construct a model that reliably predicts conversion to Cr(VI) for hypothetical activation conditions [94,95]. Many aspects of the catalyst performance, which derive from Cr(VI) conversion, can then also be forecast, including activity, melt index potential, MW distribution, LCB levels, etc. One of the conclusions from such an analysis is that the most sensitive part of an activation temperature profile is the time just before the maximum temperature is reached. The catalyst is most sensitive to moisture at the highest temperature, and because at this point the temperature is still rising, moisture levels are still relatively high. Consequently, we have found that it is better to heat the catalyst in a “convex bent” ramp rate instead of the typical linear ramp [96]. This accelerates moisture emission at low temperatures, where the catalyst is not sensitive, but slows moisture emission down at the highest temperatures where Cr(VI) is most susceptible to decomposition. A comparison is shown in Table 5 where the three ramp profiles are drawn for comparison (temperature against time). These were lab tests made with standard Cr/silica catalyst. Notice that the convex bent ramp produces higher conversion to Cr(VI). After the maximum or hold temperature is reached, the catalyst still continues to evolve moisture, although more slowly. This is due to surface annealing. Probably the remaining silanols still have some limited mobility, which allows them to condense and release water. TGA measurements were carried out on silica samples given a 30h isothermal hold at various temperatures [94,95]. The moisture evolved (sample weight loss) at each temperature is listed in Table 6 . At the lowest temperatures (200°C to 300°C) and at the highest temperature (800°C) the moisture evolution was small and quick. However, at moderate temperatures such as 600°C the moisture evolution was more gradual and the amount was much greater. Even at 30h, water was still slowly coming off. This suggests that the annealing process is slow enough at 200°C that little moisture is released within this 30-h time frame after the temperature has been reached. At 800°C the opposite condition seems to give a similar result. That is, the annealing process is rapid enough to bring the catalyst quickly to its final state of dehydroxylation before the 30h isothermal hold begins. The amount of moisture released was small at 800°C because the silanol population was already very low. However, in between these two extremes, at 600°C, the annealing process was quite visible within the experimental time frame and the amount of moisture released during the 30h isothermal hold reached its maximum. As a consequence of this isothermal annealing process one can conclude that time and temperature are somewhat interchangeable or equivalent. That is, a long time at a low temperature could be equivalent to a short time at a higher temperature. To test this idea, a series of laboratory experiments were conducted in which Cr/silica catalyst samples were calcined at various temperatures for only 15min and also for 20h. Polymerization runs were then conducted with each and the polymer was analyzed. The results are shown in Table 7 . The activity of the catalyst is shown in the table, along with various polymer characteristics. The melt index and high load melt index (HLMI) are commercial measurements of the fluidity of the molten polymer. Also shown are the molecular weight, the breadth of the MW distribution (Mw/Mn), and the Carreau-Yasuda “a” parameter (CY-a), an indication of the molten polymer’s relaxation time distribution, which is related to long-chain branch content. For each of these parameters, notice that the range covered at each temperature, 15min versus 20h, usually overlaps with its neighboring group’s range. For example, although activity (or melt index or HLMI) rise with temperature, notice that 20h at 500°C gives higher values than 15min at 600°C. Similarly, Mw (or Mw/Mn or CY-a) drops with temperature, but 20h at 500°C gives lower values than 15min at 600°C. Thus time and temperature can be said to be equivalent to some degree. This principle has been used in commercial operations to speed up the process of catalyst calcination so that equipment becomes more productive. 2.5 High melt index activations 2.5.1 Enhanced sensitivity to hydrogen Although the Phillips family of catalysts can produce an extremely wide variety of polymer types, its main drawback is the lack of melt index (MI) potential. That is, these catalysts naturally produce high MW polymer (i.e. low melt index). Unlike Ziegler catalysts, which can regulate polymer MW by hydrogenolysis, Phillips catalysts are usually not very sensitive to hydrogen. Instead, calcination temperature and reactor temperature become the main vehicles for MW control. The latter variable has finite limits. Over the years, the diluent in slurry reactors was changed from pentane to isopentane to finally isobutane, all in an effort to achieve higher reactor temperatures without polymer swelling, which was still not completely sufficient. In contrast, Ziegler-based processes tended to use heavier diluents like hexane because the MW can be lowered (i.e. the melt index can be raised) by adding hydrogen to the reactor. Thus, calcination temperature became the dominant MW control variable. However, the normal calcination recipes still do not provide enough MI potential for some high-MI (low-MW) polymer grades. Consequently, several special procedures were invented to extend the MI capability of commercial Cr/silica catalysts. One recipe greatly improves the sensitivity of the catalyst to hydrogen [1,97]. The trick is to first remove potential silanol ligands from the silica surface, either through high calcination temperatures (800°C–900°C) or by replacement with a small amount of fluoride added to the catalyst (typically 1–2F/nm2). A volatile fluoride salt can be directly added to the calciner. Then, after calcination in air, the catalyst is reduced in carbon monoxide at >300°C to produce Cr(II)/silica. When a few ppm of aluminum alkyl is added to the reactor, the catalyst becomes very sensitive to hydrogen as a MW regulator, like the Ziegler catalysts. We believe that this is due to the reaction of some “bare” Cr ions with aluminum alkyl to form the monodentate-bonded Cr species as shown in Scheme 7 (see also Scheme 6). It is interesting that with such catalysts the melt index can move from extremely low to extremely high upon the addition of H2 to the reactor, indicating drastic lowering of the polymer molecular weight. The MW distribution broadens, becoming highly skewed to the low-MW side, as might be expected from Scheme 7. If the fluoride is omitted during calcination at 600°C, or if the reducing treatment in CO is omitted, or if the aluminum alkyl is omitted, there is no improvement in sensitivity to H2. An example is shown in Table 8 . Notice that even in the presence of hydrogen the usual catalysts produce low MI (melt index) and HLMI (high load melt index) polymer. However, the combination of fluoridation or high calcination temperature (800°C), reduction in CO, and the presence of an aluminum alkyl cocatalyst, dramatically increases the sensitivity of the catalyst to hydrogen, which lowers the molecular weight of the polymer (i.e. raises the melt index or HLMI). 2.5.2 Chemical dehydroxylation Another specialized activation procedure invented to produce higher melt index is to extend, by chemical means, the usual thermal dehydroxylation process which takes place during the normal calcination (shown above in Scheme 1 and in Table 1). In this modified calcination recipe the silica is first calcined at 600°C–900°C in carbon monoxide, which further dehydroxylates the surface via the water-gas shift reaction [1,98,99], as shown in Scheme 8 . Then the chromium is added in a way that will not re-hydroxylate the silica, followed by calcination in dry air or oxygen, usually at a lower-temperature, in order to oxidize the chromium into surface-anchored Cr(VI) species. This procedure greatly enhances the natural MI-potential of the Cr(VI)/silica catalyst, without greatly changing other polymer characteristics, such as the MW distribution or comonomer incorporation. The chromium can be applied, for example, by using a hydrocarbon solution of any organo-Cr compound, or by dissolving CrO3 in CH3CN solvent, or by gas phase deposition such as sublimation of Cr(acac)3 or evaporation of CrO2Cl2. In addition to carbon monoxide, organo-sulfur compounds are especially effective at dehydroxylation [1,26,99], through an unknown mechanism, but probably similar to that shown in Scheme 8. Examples of effective organo-sulfur compounds include COS, CS2, and Et2S. Molecular sulfur or H2S are not effective, unless accompanied by CO or other source of carbon. Usually molecular sulfur is produced as a by-product during the dehydroxylation. Sulfur (or sulfide) is not left behind on the support after the final calcination in air. Selenium and tellurium compounds, although highly toxic, were found to be equally effective at dehydroxylation [100]. An example of chemical dehydroxylation is shown in Table 9 . Silica samples were calcined at various temperatures in one of three atmospheres: 1) dry air, 2) CO, or 3) N2 into which a small amount of CS2 was evaporated. In each series, the silanol population was found to decrease with temperature, but it did not reach zero even at the highest temperatures. Notice that when calcined in CO the silanol population further dropped starting at about 500°C and above. This is the water-gas shift reaction, and it is significant. In the CS2 series, there is a further loss of silanols, this time starting at as low as 400°C, with the OH population approaching zero at 900°C. These silica samples were then impregnated with CrO3 dissolved in CH3CN. After evaporation of the solvent, they were calcined again at the same temperature (shown in the table) but this time in dry air. These catalysts were quite active in polymerization tests, and the resultant polymer melt index is shown in Table 9. As expected, in each series there is a large increase in melt index with rising calcination temperature. However, notice that the catalysts calcined in CO produced a significantly higher melt index, starting above 500°C. Likewise, the catalysts calcined in CS2 produced even greater melt index, starting as low as 400°C. This is the result of enhanced dehydroxylation, or annealing, of the silica surface. It is also interesting that an unusual color change results from dehydroxylation using sulfur compounds, to a deep red as shown in Fig. 1. It can perhaps be thought of as an extension of the same color progression from yellow to orange with rising calcination temperature in dry air. This is suspected to be due to a greater abundance of dichromate instead of chromate, but it has not yet been investigated by spectroscopy in the literature. If this reasoning is correct, then the deeper reddish color derived from sulfur is also due to a still higher concentration of dichromate surface species. Sulfur is burned away during the calcination in air, and is not detected on the final catalyst. The MW distribution of the polymer is also consistent with the idea of extended dehydroxylation. There was no great change in the MW distribution, only a gradual further narrowing and shift to lower MW, as is also seen from calcination in dry air with rising temperature. Long chain branching was also measured, and found to likewise make a continuous trend, always rising with dehydroxylation. Another method of chemical dehydroxylation was also found to be effective. A small amount of Br2 or I2 vapor was introduced into the CO calcination stream. This produced a surface bromide or iodide which could be easily measured by titration [101]. In fact the halide uptake was 2–3 halides per nm2, which is considerably more than the OH population after calcination at the same temperature, suggesting that siloxanes have also reacted to cover most of the surface with halide, probably as Si-Br or Si-I. Then the samples were calcined again, but in dry air. Immediately a dark red or violet vapor was observed from the release of Br2 or I2. When impregnated with anhydrous chromium, this procedure also produced enhanced melt index potential, usually greater than that of CO alone but less than that observed from CS2. Calcination of the halided silica in H2 removed the halide as HBr or HI, leaving a hydrophobic Si-H surface [101]. Oxidation of the iodinated silica in air at high temperatures did not release all of the iodine. Curiously, it produced a color change to yellow-orange, indicating a residual unknown surface iodate species, which was stable at 900°C and found to be strongly paramagnetic. The oxidizing capacity could be measured in aqueous titrations. The unknown iodate species was destroyed by calcination in CO, but could be regenerated by further calcination in dry air, indicating its reversible transition between an unknown iodate species and iodide, without being released as I2 vapor. Another MI-enhancing effect of chemical dehydroxylation is a preservation of the silica porosity. Normally there is a loss in surface area and pore volume as the calcination temperature approaches the sintering point, typically between 800°C and 900°C, which can be considered as the earliest stages of melting. However, when the support is calcined in CO or an organo-sulfur vapor, the sintering point is shifted to higher temperatures. This probably indicates the importance of moisture, perhaps in the vapor stream, as a flux during sintering. Its removal by such chemical methods retards the sintering process. An example is shown in Table 10 . Notice the difference in porosity between calcination in air versus CO. The general increase in melt index potential at all temperatures also coincides with a shift in the sintering point, allowing even higher temperatures to be used for maximum MI without loss in porosity. 2.5.3 Two-step calcination This type of specialized activation, that is, calcination followed by anhydrous chromium deposition, then another calcination step at equal or lower temperature, is referred to as the “two-step” activation because two calcination treatments are used. This is to distinguish it from the usual “one-step” activation in which Cr/silica is simply calcined in dry air. Surprisingly, the two-step activation was found to enhance melt index (lower the polymer MW) even in the absence of chemical dehydroxylation, especially when the support is silica-titania. The two-step process is shown in Fig. 11 . Silica-titania samples were calcined in dry air at the temperature indicated by the x-axis, then treated with CrO3 in CH3CN, and finally calcined again in dry air as labeled under each curve. Notice that the melt index in each series depends on the dehydroxylation temperature (the first calcination) in the same way listed in Table 1, with MI rising as the temperature did up to the sintering point. However, as the Cr attachment temperature (the second calcination) is lowered, the MI of each curve rises even higher, indicating that anhydrous Cr attaches in a different way compared to the aqueous “one-step” control activation. A high-MI species is formed that is thermally unstable at the higher temperatures. This has not yet been investigated in the literature via spectroscopic means. The effect is most prominent when the support contains titania but it is also observed on plain silica to a lesser extent. When the “two-step” procedure is used in combination with chemical dehydroxylation as well, the MI enhancement is even greater. The change in chromium bonding during the secondary calcination step was demonstrated in another experiment [102]. Cr/silica-titania was first calcined in dry air at 760°C. Then it was slurried in hexane to which four moles of t-butanol was added per mole of Cr(VI) on the catalyst. The initial orange color of the catalyst changed to yellow and the hexane also changed to a yellow color, indicating the formation and dissolution of probably t-butyl chromate. The hexane was then evaporated and the catalyst re-activated in dry air at only 315°C. When it was tested for polymerization activity, the polymer was found to have a 250% increase in melt index over the original untreated catalyst. When calcined at 540°C the melt index improvement dropped to only a 30% rise over the original catalyst. The experiment was repeated using a different Cr/silica-titania that was first calcined in air at 800°C, then treated with 1 t-butanol/Cr, and finally it was calcined again at 300°C. This catalyst produced a 10-fold improvement in melt index over the original untreated catalyst. These experiments show that the chromium did indeed come off the surface, only to be re-deposited in some different way, making the high-MI Cr species. 2.5.4 R&R activation Actually all of the benefits of the two-step activation can be achieved without depositing the chromium anhydrously in a separate step. If normal virgin Cr(III)/silica catalyst is calcined in CO at high temperature, Cr(II) and Cr(III) oxides are formed, possibly as crystallites or domains, which exhibit little polymerization activity. However, if air is then added, these are oxidized to Cr(VI) and the catalyst becomes active for ethylene polymerization. If the air is added at a lower temperature than was used in the CO treatment, then the Cr(VI) attaches to the support to form the same thermally unstable high-MI species noted above. This process is called reduction and reoxidation, or “R&R” activation [1,99]. It is easy to conduct on a commercial scale and it offers the same three advantages of 1) chemical dehydroxylation, 2) two-step type Cr attachment, and 3) retardation of sintering. If the reduction step is carried out in CS2 instead of CO, chromium sulfides are formed instead of the oxides. However, these also are oxidized back to the Cr(VI) oxide in the second step, with a similar enhancement in MI comparable to the two-step process using CS2. Oxidation produces the same unusual reddish color and sulfur is no longer found on the catalyst. Nitrogen can also be used as the “reducing agent” in R&R activation. Usually the commercial catalysts initially contain Cr(III) acetate. If they are calcined in nitrogen, the chromium is converted to Cr2O3, which can then be oxidized to the desired high-MI Cr(VI) species if the catalyst is subjected to air at a lower temperature. Of course, using nitrogen as the “reducing agent” does not provide the benefits of chemical dehydroxylation or retardation of sintering. Nevertheless, the MI improvement in commercial operations can be significant using the R&R recipe with nitrogen only. Table 11 shows some examples of R&R activation. In each experiment a Cr/silica-titania sample was treated (or reduced) at 870°C in an atmosphere of either N2, CO or CS2. Then the catalysts were reoxidized in dry air at the temperature listed. The melt index produced by each catalyst is listed in the table. Notice again that the CS2-reduced catalysts yield higher MI values than the CO series which are in turn higher than those treated in only nitrogen. The molecular weight of these polymers is also listed in the table, which decrease as the melt index values rise. Notice also that within each series the melt index goes through a maximum (and the MW through a minimum) after oxidation at about 600°C. This is because a certain amount of temperature is needed to efficiently reoxidize the chromium, but above that point the thermally unstable high-MI Cr species begins to revert back to ordinary Cr bonding. 2.6 Catalyst activation in the future Predicting the future is always difficult, but some trends are already clear enough that they can probably be extrapolated into the future with some confidence. Below are a few examples of recent progress made in some areas, and no doubt there will be many more in the future. Cost and quality are the two largest drivers for innovation, but some of the items below also offer the potential to enhance safety, and produce new products. 2.6.1 Ideal calcination recipe In Fig. 12 the traditional activation profile is plotted in which the temperature is ramped up linearly to the set point, where it is held for a prolonged period, and then it is ramped back down linearly. There was no particular reason for this historical profile, other than simplicity. The ideal profile, taking into account the principles outlined above, is also plotted in Fig. 12 for comparison. It has a curved (bent) ramp which is fast at the low temperatures and slow at the higher temperatures. It shortens the hold period considerably by using a slightly higher temperature. The net result is higher output from the calciner, which is sometimes the main bottleneck of a plant, and often better catalyst performance is also obtained. Such activation profiles are now being incorporated into numerous plants around the world, with the recipe tailored to each catalyst, plant and resin grade. 2.6.2 Continuous activation At present commercial calcination recipes have all been designed for a batch process, which is universally used throughout the HDPE industry. However, in recent years Chevron Phillips, in conjunction with Procedyne Corp., has designed and built a continuous calciner [103]. This has the great advantage of not requiring the routine, almost daily, thermal cycling of the batch process, which fatigues the equipment and increases maintenance requirements. Instead of ramping the temperature up and then back down to discharge a cooled catalyst, in the continuous calciner the catalyst moves through various heating zones which are held at a constant temperature. The lack of thermal cycling also improves the energy efficiency of the unit. A drawing of the continuous calciner is shown in Fig. 13 . The continuous calciner still uses a fluidized bed, and takes advantage of all the principles outlined above, that is: 1) a very shallow bed and therefore a much higher space velocity than the typical batch calciner, 2) the bent ramp for fast initial heating which is slowed down later to protect the catalyst at its most critical point, 3) the trading of temperature for time, and 4) instantaneous cooling at the end of the cycle, which is not possible with a batch process. Because of the third and fourth principles, the calciner is much smaller (with lower investment costs) than the normal batch calciner. In comparison to the batch process this new and quite small continuous calciner can activate catalyst at a rate beyond the largest commercial batch calciner, and also with improved conversion to Cr(VI). 2.6.3 Fast activating catalyst The highest commercial activation temperature we are aware of is about 900°C. Above this point the equipment itself is at risk. This temperature also puts the catalyst into the sintering zone, as shown in Table 9. In fact, some of the oldest calcination recipes rely on long hold times (up to 30h) at such high temperatures. It was observed early by plant engineers that such extremes were useful to control swell during blow-molding in some HDPE grades. Although the underlying reason was not initially understood, today we know that the catalyst is being sintered, which reinforces its structure by lowering its porosity. This is now known to enhance long-chain branching which controls molding behavior in general, and swell in particular [104–106]. Given that it is reinforcement of catalyst structure that underlies the valued swell behavior, new grades of catalyst are being introduced in which the silica has already been reinforced before calcination. This is easily done during silica manufacture through a chemical process called Oswald ripening [107]. This allows the PE producer to achieve the same result at less extreme temperatures and with much shorter hold times, which serves to debottleneck the calciner, and sometimes even plant polymer production too. 2.6.4 In-Situ catalyst formation The mobility of the chromium during calcination can be used as a way of making Cr(VI)/silica catalysts in the plant. In some commercial tests at a Chevron-Phillips plant, plain silica was mixed in a 1:1 ratio with standard catalyst containing 1% Cr loading. Normally this loading is too high by a factor of two or three, because in some recipes only 30–50% of the chromium is converted to Cr(VI). During the calcination the excess chromium from the standard catalyst was transferred to the silica to create additional catalyst in-situ. This opens up the commercial silica market because there are many silica manufacturers but only a few Cr/silica producers. Silica tends to sell at a lower price than catalyst because of the larger market (silica is used to manufacture beer, toothpaste, desiccants, etc.). It also avoids the shipping of chromium-containing catalyst around the world. And there is a much wider diversity of silica grades available, many as yet unexplored for polymerization catalysis. This approach allows one to tailor the Cr loading for specific applications (long-chain branching is a function of Cr loading [108–110]). Pure chromium compounds can also be used to make catalyst from silica in the calciner. The compound is simply dropped into the activator along with the silica, and fluidized in air as the temperature is raised. Cr(acac)3 is particularly useful because it sublimes at low temperature. Thus it can be charged to the calciner along with the silica, and as the temperature is raised in air it reacts with the silica and is converted to the conventional Cr(VI) precursor. Because Cr(VI) is mobile, other Cr compounds also work, including even Cr2O3 powder. 2.6.5 Enhanced acidity As noted above, calcination is thought to generate active sites by increasing electron deficiency on the chromium. This is also the role of solid acids, long used by Chevron Phillips to ionize (or “activate”) metallocenes [111,112]. Some of these same solid acid supports can also stabilize Cr(VI) to produce some very active Phillips catalysts that yield unexpected new polymer properties [113]. Typically these solid acids contain a Lewis-acidic metal, such as Al, B, Ti, Zr, Fe, Sc, Zn etc., whose acid strength is then amplified by the application of an electron-withdrawing anion, such as sulfate, halide, phosphate, triflate, halo-carboxylate, fluoroborate, etc, and their combinations. Often the most convenient method of applying the anion is in the gas phase during the calcination step. For example, chloride can be incorporated by the addition of chlorocarbon or SiCl4 vapor [114], fluoride by the addition of Freon [115], and sulfate by the addition of ammonium sulfate [116]. The vapors generated by thermal decomposition of these compounds are then quantitatively adsorbed by the support during the calcination. The addition of acidity tends to make the catalyst more active. For example, adding sulfate to Cr/alumina catalyst yields a five-fold improvement in activity [116]. It also provides the lowest concentration of long-chain branching we have found in any polymer made from Phillips-type catalysts. This, and a major narrowing of the MW distribution, results in exceedingly low relaxation times, even for near ultra-high MW PE [117]. This greatly aids the molding operations during film and pipe manufacture, because it relieves molecular stresses generated during extrusion that can otherwise be frozen into the finished part. In fact this catalyst was used to develop the world’s first PE-100 pipe resin using a single catalyst and a single reactor, which greatly simplifies the manufacturing process compared to traditional dual-reactor bimodal technology. In addition to Cr/alumina, Cr/silica catalysts can also be treated with sulfate and phosphate to boost the melt index potential, that is lower the polymer molecular weight [118]. 2.6.6 Cr(III) catalysts The solid acids described above have been found to “activate” many different metal compounds to form quite active polymerization catalysts. Some examples of this are organic salts of trivalent chromium, such as longer-chain carboxylates, naphthenates, and diketonates [119]. The latter group of compounds is particularly useful because they sublime at low temperatures. Thus, a small amount of, for example, chromium (acac)3 can be dropped into the calciner at the end of the cycle when the solid acid is in nitrogen at 100–200°C. It sublimes and reacts to form an active catalyst. However, this calcination recipe does not produce the usual hexavalent precursor. Instead, the final deposition is done in nitrogen so that the chromium remains in the trivalent form. Nevertheless, it is quite active for ethylene polymerization. Thus, there is no possibility of worker exposure to carcinogenic Cr(VI) and no transportation of drums of Cr catalyst, because the trivalent catalyst is formed in the plant. These trivalent catalysts are quite unusual in their behavior in comparison to the typical commercial Cr(VI)/silica catalyst. They are very sensitive to hydrogen as a MW regulator, unlike their hexavalent counterparts. They produce a broad MW distribution of extremely linear polymer, that is, having very low amounts of long-chain branching. The MW distribution can also be widely manipulated by varying the solid acid support. 3 Conclusions The calcination of the Phillips Cr/silica catalyst not only “activates” it, but controls all of the polymer properties as well. With rising calcination temperature comes higher polymerization activity, lower polymer molecular weight, better comonomer incorporation, and higher levels of long-chain branching. This is probably caused by an increase in the number of active sites, and also in the Lewis acidity of those chromium sites. Greater electron deficiency can favor agostic β-hydride coordination, which is a necessary prelude for chain termination. Likewise, the greater positive charge on the chromium also improves reactivity with α-olefins relative to ethylene, owing to their greater electron donating ability. The same can be said for macromer incorporation, which leads to long-chain branching and increased melt elasticity. The breadth of the polymer MW distribution reflects the diversity of active sites on the silica surface, which is also a strong function of the calcination history. This diversity is apparent in the length of the induction time, and the sharpness of the rising kinetic profile. The average molecular weight rises with time, indicating that the slowest sites to come on stream produce the longest chains. This initiation process can be accelerated by first reducing all the Cr(VI) to Cr(II) with carbon monoxide. Such Cr(II) catalysts perform similar to Cr(VI) catalysts, although with some peculiarities, and can often be used interchangeably in commercial operations, which suggests similar active sites. Partial reduction of the Cr(VI) at low temperature, and poisoning of the Cr(II) product with CO, provides another means of identifying site diversity. The Cr(VI) sites that react last with CO again produce the longest chains. Calcination changes the chromium in multiple ways. It converts the initial domains of chromium (III) acetate into individual surface-bound Cr(VI) species, which are highly mobile during calcination. It removes potential silanol ligands nearby, and it converts some chromate species into dichromate. Because Cr(VI) is mobile on the surface it seems likely that, at ever higher temperatures where ever more widely-spaced silanols are generated, Cr(VI) can still occupy and bridge some these silanol pairs to reduce surface energy, but also to create strain in the Cr(VI) bonding. Such strain would produce more positive charge on the metal as ligands are pulled out of orbitals. The lack of nearby ligands would also increase coordinative unsaturation. It is not known if dichromate species can produce active sites, but it seems likely. Thus the net result of all of this variety in the chromium environment is a highly shear-thinning polymer having a broad MW distribution, one that can be manipulated in many ways through calcination. The calcination process can also be enhanced and extended by chemical means, namely through the water-gas shift reaction with carbon monoxide, or a similar reaction with organo-sulfur compounds or even halides. Such chemically treated catalysts display the same trends observed from simple thermal treatment in air, only extrapolated beyond the usual thermal limits. Activity is improved, polymer molecular weight is lowered, melt index is increased, and the MW distribution further narrowed. The CO R&R recipe is very useful in some commercial applications requiring high melt index. Commercial calcination provides a unique set of challenges, namely maximizing production while minimizing exposure of the catalyst to self-generated moisture at high temperatures, which can decompose Cr(VI) species to inactive α-Cr2O3. The silica annealing process has a time and temperature dependence, which often permits the exchange of one for the other in some recipes. This understanding has led to the development of a variety of new calcination recipes aimed at enhanced manufacturing efficiency and new polymer architectures. A: Gen. 527 2016 116 126 Max P. McDaniel completed his Ph.D. studies on chromia at Northwestern University in 1973 under R.L. Burwell, and then went on to work on titania catalysis for one year as a Chercheur Associé at the Institut Catalyse in Lyon, France. In 1975 McDaniel accepted a research position at Phillips Petroleum where, for over four decades, he has lead a small group of scientists in the invention and commercialization of new polymerization catalysts and polymers at the Phillips Research Center in Oklahoma. There, he has contributed a number of important technology breakthroughs in HDPE catalysis and manufacturing for Phillips (now Chevron Phillips) and its family of worldwide licensees. McDaniel has received numerous recognitions, including the Southwest Regional ACS Chemist of the Year award, the ACS Hero of Chemistry award, the ACS Oklahoma Chemist of the Year, the Oklahoma Bar Association Inventor of the Year, a Distinguished Corporate Inventor by the Inventor Hall of Fame in Akron, R&D Magazine’s Top 100 New Product Award, and many Phillips and Chevron Phillips most significant invention awards. McDaniel has authored over 350 US patents and more than 100 scientific publications and lectures, including a 2016 return to Lyon in a visiting lecturer position. His contributions include advancements in Cr/silica catalysts, metallocene activation, ethylene trimerization, and high performance polymers for blow molding, pipe, sheet, geomembrane and film.

coredata.dc:description: More than any other parameter, the calcination process is capable of modifying the performance of the Cr/silica catalyst system (also known as Phillips-type catalysts) to generate activity and to influence the diverse active population in order to produce a wide variety of different polymer characteristics. This includes the polymer molecular weight, the shape and breadth of the MW distribution, the efficiency of comonomer and macromer incorporation, and the location of both short-chain and long-chain branches within the MW distribution. These fundamental polymer characteristics control how the polymer behaves during molding operations and they influence every physical property of the finished HDPE part. For this reason, a considerable number of calcination recipes have been developed over 60 years of commercial use to tailor the polymer characteristics for various HDPE applications. This is done by manipulating the relative amounts of differing active sites on the catalyst. This report attempts to explain the chemistry involved in the calcination process, to show how it can be controlled in various ways to achieve commercial ends, and to extrapolate these trends to predict the future of catalyst activation in the HDPE industry.
coredata.dc:title: Manipulating polymerization chemistry of Cr/silica catalysts through calcination
